column2: Let it snow!
What you'll do
This is OS hacking at it's finest. Spectacular effects for your desktop. Learn about GNOME Shell extensions, CSS and emojis.

As you all know I have a passion for art. For as long as there has been art, artists have been enthused by nature. I am fascinated by the beauty of snow crystals. And today I would like to bring that beauty to your computing environment.
Thank you Estelle for that lovely introduction. As we say around here: Let the snow begin!

So for the next experiment we need to modify our Operating System, the Graphical user interface to it to be more precise. We can do this by adding so called Shell extensions, tiny programs that add something special to your Desktop. There are lots of different extensions that you can explore here: https://extensions.gnome.org/ Riley will walk you though the setup process. We had hacking the OS in class just recently.

Now that the Snow extension is installed, we need to enable it. To do so, we need to install a little app that lets you manage extensions.
Every extension that you have installed can be either enabled or disabled. So next we need to enable the Snow extension. Check the Desktop for the Extensions app, and launch it.
This application shows all your extensions - you can enable or disable each one using the switch on the right.
Look for the Snow extension, and click the switch to the right of it to enable it.

Do you see the button on the left side of the Extensions app? If you click on it, you can flip the Extensions app and hack it!
Great! Here's the tooblox of the Extensions app. Play around with the controls to change how the snow falls. Try changing the snowflakes to "üò∫Ô∏è", and make it snow cats!

You can also change the actual code in the Toolbox. I think you've already figured out that this extension uses emoji for its snowflakes - but did you know you can also use a list of emoji for the snowflakes, not just a single one?
There's a list of emoji at https://emojipedia.org/ Using that website, you can look for any emoji and copy with ctrl + c, then paste it into the code with ctrl + v.
There's an easier way to look for an emoji on some modern systems - Try clicking in the text editor, then pressing ctrl + . - On most GNOME systems, that should show the emoji picker.

There's yet another way that you can modify the snow! Click the Styles tab on the left side of the Toolbox!

The snow is defined using CSS, just like you've used on webpages in other activities. If you haven't seen CSS yet, you can try out some of the activities in the Web Pathway and see what it's all about. For the snow, though, you don't really need to know much.
Look at the code, here - there's a snowflake class that defines all snowflakes, and then we have 3 more classes that are randomly assigned to every snowflake - snowflake1, snowflake2 and snowflake3

Those three classses each modify a snowflake in a different way - that's why some snowflakes are bigger than others. Try changing the number after font-size, and then click on the Let it snow! button to see the result of your changes!
You can also play with colors. If you look in the snowflake class, you can see that there's a color set for all the snowflakes.

To change the color of one of the larger or smaller snowflakes, copy the color line from snowflake into snowflake1. Then you can change the color to something else. If you don't have any ideas, give red (#f00) a shot!
Shell extensions sure are cool, huh? They're powerful ... but that means you have to be careful which ones you install, because they could really mess up your system. Be careful, but have fun!
